Description: Attic red-figured pottery bell-krater with lug handles, reconstructed (from numerous fragments and much plaster); interior glazed black; exterior: red-figure laurel leaf and berry pattern on lip; at top of wall, egg pattern frieze; on side A, banquet scene; from left, female figure to right (head with fillet in added white in hair, and part of mantle with white decoration preserved), facing reclining (?a non-joining fragment with kline and mattress is placed below him) youth (top of head, wearing fillet, and right arm holding up cup); on other fragments, second reclining youth (upper body with wreath with white in hair, naked torso, part of cushion and kline remaining, reclining with head turned to right); small table with objects in white in front of first reclining pair; second female figure standing to right playing the flute (top of hair, part of himation, and end of aulos flute - on separate fragment, remaining); on next set of fragments reclining youth (upper body with white wreath in hair, naked torso, cloak around waist); fourth reclining youth (wreath in hair, naked torso, cloak around waist), pillows and kline; table with offerings in white; inscription above figures; below each handle, palmettes and tendrils; on panel B, a banqueting scene (at left, cloaked back of figure remaining; at right head with white fillet and himation of female flute player; right hand of banqueter holding a kotyle; top of hair of possibly second female figure remaining); below panels, maeander and cross pattern frieze; remainder of pot is plaster.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 5, pl. 10. no. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1009)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Mabinau
